column5: Sun of Faith - English (orange = English translation changed from existing)
Chapter 20: Searching for the Path
After spending a few days in those places, the Bodhisattva wondered: “What distance separates us from Kapilavastu?”
column8: དེ་ནས་གྲོང་ཁྱེར་རྒྱལ་པོའི་ཁབ་ཀྱི་ཁང་བཟང་གི་རྩེ་མོ་ནས།  རྒྱལ་པོ་གཟུགས་ཅན་སྙིང་པོས་ལྟ་བ་དང་། ལམ་སྲང་ན་བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་ཤིང་ལོ་ཙེམས་པའི་ལྷུང་བཟེད་བསྣམས་ཏེ་བསོད་སྙོམས་མཛད་པ་དང་། བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་ཤིང་དྲུང་དུ་བཞུགས་པའི་དྲུང་དུ། རྒྱལ་པོ་འཁོར་བཅས་བྱོན་ཏེ་ཞུ་བ་མཛད་པ་འབྲི། དེ་དང་ཉེ་བའི་ནགས་གཅིག་ཏུ། དྲང་སྲོང་ལ་ལ་རྐང་པ་ཡ་གཅིག་འབྲེང་བ་དང་། ལ་ལ་མེ་ལྔ་གདུང་བ་དང་། ལ་ལ་ཆུ་ལ་ཞུགས་བ་དང་།  ལ་ལ་དུ་བ་འཐུང་བ་ལ་སོགས་པ་དང་། བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་ཡང་དཀའ་ཐུབ་དེ་གཉིས་ལྡབས་སུ་མཛད་པ་འབྲི། དེ་ནས་ཡང་ནགས་གཞན་ཞིག་ཏུ། ལོ་མའི་སྐྱལ་པོ་ན། དྲང་སྲོང་རིང་འཕུར་ཡོད་པ་འཁོར་བཅས་ཀྱི་དྲུང་དུ་བྱོན་པ་དང་།  ཡང་ལྷག་སྤྱོད་ཀྱི་དྲུང་དུ་བྱོན་པ་ཡང་དེ་ཁོ་ན་འདྲ་བ་དང་། འདིའི་རིང་ཕུར་དང་ལྷག་སྤྱོད་ནི། གོང་གི་སྟོན་པ་དྲུག་གསུམ་བཅོ་བརྒྱད་ཀྱི་སྙོམས་འཇུག་པ་དྲུག་གི་ནང་ཚན་ཡིན།
column9: In Rājagṛha (rgyal po’i khab), from the palace, King Bimbisāra (gzugs can snying po) sees the Buddha begging for alms. The king then goes to a forest to visit the Buddha. The Buddha visits sages performing ascetic practices such as standing on a single leg, fire torment, walking on the water, and swallowing smoke and so forth in a forest. The Buddha also performs two of these practices. In a forest, the Buddha visits the sage, Ārāḍa-kālāma (ring ‘phur) dwelling in a hut. He then visits the sage, Udraka-rāmaputra (lhag spyod) in a hut.

column5: “Twelve leagues,” [the ascetics] responded.
“That’s still not far enough,” he decided.
Crossing the Ganges, he traced his way back to the valley and finally arrived in Rajagrha.
Carrying an oleander leaf as his begging bowl he entered the city to seek alms.
Bimbisara (Gzugs can snying po) who ruled over Rajagrha, caught sight of the Bodhisattva from his palace balcony.

Following the Bodhisattva with his eyes, he praised him elaborately, and added: “Our city is used to welcoming all sorts of waifs and strays but not one of them has ever walked into it with such dignity.”
column12: This section is much more extensive in the Vinaya passage with Bimbasara waxing eloquent on the qualities of the Bodhisattva in a series of Ślokas (seven-syllable lines)

column5: Siddhartha moved on and came to rest under a patala tree, also known as the ‘silvery one’ (skya seng), which was growing at the foot of the mountain.
Bimbisara had the Bodhisattva shadowed by his spies, and having thus got to know of the spot where he was to be found, [went there, and] introduced himself and all his court to him.
Greeting the Bodhisattva with words of respect and friendship, the king went on to say:
“Mendicancy is a way of life beneath the dignity of a young man in good health.
Allow me to offer you a life of pleasure and luxury. What caste do you belong to? What is your line of descent?”
“O king, near the snow-covered mountains there is a country, rich in grain And endowed with all riches, renowned as Kosala.
column12: These next verses are taken nearly verbatim from the Vinaya passage—with some small modifications.

column5: There live the Śākyas, who belong to the Pundra clan who are descendants of the sun. I, O King, am a royal prince [of that clan], but I, myself, no longer strive for wealth or pleasure."
column12: Between these stanzas and the next, Taranatha elides two stanzas (4 lines of nine syllables) from the Vinaya passage that explain that the bounty and beauty of his homeland would just make ascetic practice difficult.

column5: He continued: “Your Majesty, ever since I came into this world,  desires have filled me with a profound repugnance.
I have only just managed to repel these terrifying enemies of the spiritual path – why would I take up with them again?”
In this way he went on explaining at length his decision [to give up the delights of the world] to Bimbisara.
[Bimbisara] then asked the bodhisattva, "What do you intend to achieve with this vow, honorable sir?"
"Perfect awakening!" replied the bodhisattva.
[Bimbisara] then entreated, “when you obtain that [awakening], please spare a thought for me!”
“At that time, I will think of you.” Siddhartha promised.

The next stage on his journey brought the Bodhisattva to a cluster of hermitages close to Gṛdhrakūṭa (Mt. Vulture Heap, Bya rgod phung po’i ri), where holy men were involved in ascetic practices of various kinds.
Some made themselves endure the ‘torture of the five fires,’ others stood stock-still on one leg and so on.
column7: Torture of the five fires. Diffusing smoke. Swimming. Dwelling place of various sages.

column5: The Bodhisattva tried each technique in turn and inflicted upon himself the double of what the other anchorites inflicted upon themselves.
Because of this they named him the "Great Sage" (drang srong chen po, dge sbyong chen po).
But soon enough, he realized that all such practitioners had but one goal in view: to be reborn in one of the celestial realms.
column12: The canonical passage includes references to the following realms: that of Indra (brgya byin nyid), Brahmā (tshang pa nyid), and Māra (bdud nyid). [17b.2]

column5: Moreover, he understood that, once reborn once in a celestial world, they would soon fall back, given the incomplete nature of their path, into the deepest depths of the cycle of existence.
He therefore left this spot and set off for the hermitage of Arāda-kālāma (sgyu rtsal shes kyi bu ring du phur ba).
column7: Sage Arāda-kālāma Udraka-rāmaputra At the dwelling of Arāda-kālāma and Udraka-rāmaputra

column5: From Arāda-kālāma, the Bodhisattva received oral instructions on the practices which lead to ‘the dimension where nothing exists.’
The same evening he attained the ultimate result of that meditation.
At first light, he asked Arada-kalama: “Have you yourself reached the point of your technique which culminates in the dimension where nothing exists?"
“I have.”
“I too succeeded in reaching it."
“In that case,” the master joyously exclaimed, “we are equals. Join forces with me. We will jointly guide these disciples.”

Although Arāda-kālāma showed great respect to the Bodhisattva and praised his qualities, Siddhartha already had understood that on its own, that path would lead him neither to knowledge, nor to perfect vision – let alone to Buddhahood.
Therefore he moved on to find Udraka-rāmaputra (lhag spyod rengs byed kyi bu).
Everything happened exactly as it had at Arāda-kālāma's place—

save one thing: this time around, the Bodhisattva was able to reach and explore the dimension in which the mind is neither provided with nor deprived of knowingness, attaining the state of meditative absorption called the ‘pinnacle of existence.’
Then he left Udraka-rāmaputra’s hermitage and set forth for other regions.
